title.value: Invasive Brain Computer Interface for Motor Restoration in Spinal Cord Injury: A Systematic Review
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned in the input text.
title.quote: Invasive Brain Computer Interface for Motor Restoration in Spinal Cord Injury: A Systematic Review

extractions.description: This paper is a systematic review reviewing invasive closed-loop brain-computer interface (BCI) technologies for the treatment of spinal cord injury (SCI) in humans. It examines the techniques and outcomes used in the included studies.

type.justification: The study is empirical because it is based on systematic review of existing studies and data.
type.quote: Study design: Systematic review of the literature.

name.justification: The primary research field is Neuromodulation, as the paper is published in the journal 'Neuromodulation: Technology at the Neural Interface'.
name.quote: Neuromodulation: Technology at the Neural Interface

name.justification: The paper focuses on brain-computer interfaces as a treatment for SCI.
name.quote: In recent years, brain-computer interface (BCI) has emerged as a potential treatment for patients with spinal cord injury (SCI).

name.justification: The application domain is clearly spinal cord injury as it's the main focus for restoring motor function.
name.quote: This is the first systematic review of the literature on invasive closed-loop BCI technologies for the treatment of SCI in humans.

name.justification: The model is explicitly mentioned and was used to decode neural signals in the study.
name.quote: To decode these neural signals, machine learning and statistical models were used: support vector machine in eight patients (38.1%).

is_contributed.justification: Support Vector Machine is a well-known model and is used in the study, not contributed by it.
is_contributed.quote: support vector machine in eight patients (38.1%)

is_executed.justification: The study mentions execution of the model.
is_executed.quote: support vector machine in eight patients (38.1%)

is_compared.justification: The study compares different models for decoding neural signals.
is_compared.quote: machine learning and statistical models were used: support vector machine...
